Ref Table(s).31: PPDM_SYSTEMPPDM_TABLE_ALIASPPDM_TABLEPPDM_PROCEDUREPPDM_INDEX PPDM_COLUMNPPDM_CODE_VERSIONPPDM_CONSTRAINTPPDM_COLUMN_ALIAS
Ref Table(s).33: PPDM_TABLE_ALIASPPDM_TABLE PPDM_INDEXPPDM_COLUMNPPDM_CODE_VERSIONPPDM_CONSTRAINTPPDM_COLUMN_ALIAS

Column Comment.0: PPDM GROUP IDENTIFIER: Unique ID for the table used to track associationsbetween columns in the data model and logical groupings. For example, you coulduse this table to group all columns that fall in a particular domains, such as depth, orall the columns used by a software application, or the columns used in a particularreport.
Column Comment.1: OBJECT OBSERVATION NUMBER: Unique identifier for an association between anobject and a group.
Column Comment.2: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.3: CODE VERSION OBSERVATION NUMBER: Unique number identifying the versionof the reference value that is stored in this table.
Column Comment.4: CODE VERSION SOURCE: the source for this reference code version.
Column Comment.5: COLUMN ALIAS IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a column alias.
Column Comment.6: COLUMN NAME: Name of the column within a specific table found in the PPDMschema
Column Comment.7: CONSTRAINT IDENTIFIER: unique identifier for a primary, foreign, check or otherconstraint.
Column Comment.8: EFFECTIVE DATE: the date that the association between the column and the groupcame into effect.
Column Comment.9: EXPIRY DATE: The date that the association between the column and the group wasno longer in effect.
Column Comment.10: PPDM GROUP USE: The function or useage of a table or column in a group.Examples include direct usage, a dependency, a core part of the group or areferenced section etc.
Column Comment.11: INDEX IDENTIFIER: unique ID for the index.
Column Comment.12: PPDM OBJECT TYPE: The type of database object that is being tracked, such as atable, column, index, constraint or procedure. May also be a related object, such as abusiness rule.
Column Comment.13: FONT: A list of valid fonts, such as ARIAL or TIMES NEW ROMAN. Fonts aredesigns that govern the types of characters and symbols that can be displayed, andthe design or apperance of those displays.
Column Comment.14: COLOR: A list of valid colors. If wished, these colors may be referenced to specificpalletts. The color used for the background of this column display.
Column Comment.15: COLOR: A list of valid colors. If wished, these colors may be referenced to specificpalletts. The color used for the characters.
Column Comment.16: FONT EFFECT: The special effect assigned to this display, such as bold, italic,normal.
Column Comment.17: FONT SIZE: The size of font used for the output.
Column Comment.18: FONT SIZE UNIT OF MEASURE: the size measurement used for fonts, such aspoints, millimeters etc.
Column Comment.19: OUTPUT HEADING: the heading that should be used when outputting thisinformation to a report.
Column Comment.20: OUTPUT LENGTH: The length of the output space for this column output, oftendefined as number of spaces.
Column Comment.22: OUTPUT PRECISION: For number fields, the number of decimal places to bedisplayed
Column Comment.23: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.24: PREFERRED UNIT OF MEASURE: the unit of measure preferred for output in thisgroup. A group may be all the columns used for a report or query, or all the columnsthat are used for a function.
Column Comment.25: PROCEDURE IDENTIFIER: Identifier for procedures used for a system or table. Maybe a stored procedure, called procedure, function etc.
Column Comment.26: TABLE PROPERTY CONTROL SET IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the propertycontrol information. This can be used to help you control how a vertical table isimplemented, by determining preferred units of measure, data entry types and otherspecifications for each kind of property that is defined.
Column Comment.27: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.28: RULE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a rule. Rules may be policies, practices,procedures or system business rules.
Column Comment.29: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.30: APPLICATION NAME: Unique name code for the software application.
Column Comment.31: SYSTEM IDENTIFIER: A unique identifier for a data storage system, such as adatabase or XML schema.
Column Comment.32: TABLE ALIAS: unique identifier for a table alias or synonym that has been loadedinto a system. Most systems require these aliases to be unique, allowing naturalvalues to be used.
Column Comment.33: TABLE NAME: The name of the table within the schema.
Column Comment.34: USE RULE DESCRIPTION: A short narrative description of when this grouping orassociation should be used, or how it should be used. Primarily for referencedocumentation purposes.
Column Comment.35: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.36: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.37: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.38: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.39: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.40: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.41: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
